awd_titl_txt: GOALI:  Population Balance Modeling:  Fundamental Closures and Experimental Validation
awd_abstract_narration:
In nature, the flow of solid particles in avalanches and landslides can lead to quite devastating effects.  In industrial processing, the flow of solid particles is inherent to the production of pharmaceuticals, oil and gas, chemicals, and agricultural products. To avoid comparable adverse effects, such as industrial accidents and lost productivity, it is important to predict and control the flow of these granular systems. However, the flow of solid particles is poorly understood and not easily modeled.  Whereas models of liquid flow are a basic tenant of engineering and derived from basic physical principles, current models of solid particle flow rely on adjustable parameters, are empirical, and incorporate a number of gross simplifications.  This research project uses computer simulations and state-of-the-art experiments to develop and validate theoretical models of flows of solid particles that are based on measurable quantities.  In addition, this work supports the involvement of underrepresented groups, the training of junior researchers and students, and the involvement of students in an industrial-academic research partnership.  Results from the project will be communicated to the general public via blog posts and a Twitter account.

This project is focusing on the reliable prediction of the mass flow rate of solids when they are fluidized by the upward motion of a flowing gas. Existing empirical correlations for particle entrainment rate constants may vary by many orders of magnitude when applied to the same system. Current models are primarily limited by empiricism and development to a very particular situation. To develop a predictive understanding of fluidized granular systems, this research is deriving a closure for the continuum theory that is based on population and kinetic theory balances. The resulting model for cohesive-particle flows will require only measurable, physical quantities as inputs.  The new continuum framework is being applied to the case of humidity-induced agglomeration. Numerical modeling with discrete element method simulations is being combined with non-intrusive shadowgraphy experiments to validate the new theory. A unique aspect of the work is the development of a novel microscopic (particle-particle) cohesion model that drives the closure of the macroscopic (continuum) theory.

por.por_cntn:
Processes involving the flow of solid particles are ubiquitous in both nature (landslides, avalanches, planetary rings, etc.) and industry (pharmaceuticals, food products, chemical and petroleum industries), though a predictive understanding of their behavior remains an elusive goal.  Of particular motivation in the proposed effort is the utter unreliability of empirical correlations for particle entrainment – a recent comparative study has indicated that existing correlations vary by orders of magnitude when applied to the same system.  Based on the data sets from which these correlations have been developed, a strong case can be made for cohesive forces being a major culprit responsible for the existing discrepancies. Indeed, our GOALI industrial partner Dow Corning echoes this hypothesis based on their decades of experiences with  such systems. Hence, the overarching objective of this effort is to make a transformative leap in the continuum description of cohesive-particle flows via a fundamental approach that does not involve adjustable parameters.  A three-pronged approach will be taken that involves theory, simulations, and experiments:  (i) physically-based derivation of closures for the continuum theory (population balance and kinetic-theory balances) that do not involve the oversimplifications of past works (e.g., constant success factor of agglomeration), (ii) the demonstration of the new continuum framework for a specific case study (humidity-induced agglomeration), and (iii) stepwise validation of the new theory via DEM simulations and experiments.

A unique aspect of the proposed effort is the development of a novel microscopic (particle-particle) cohesion model that drives the closure of the macroscopic (continuum) theory. This simple yet physical model can be obtained for a given set of particles via a simple defluidization experiment using a commercial rheometer from Anton Paar.  When combined with state-of-the-art CFD-DEM simulations of the rheometer, the model parameters are extracted.  To validate the resulting model, it was applied to a different experiment - angle-of-repose-measurements.  The model predictions compared well with the experimental data, demonstrating the ability to use simple defluidization experiments for model development.

The simple particle-particle cohesion model can then be used for closure of the continuum equations.  Namely, the particle-particle model was used to simulate a number of simple systems, where data for the population balance closure was obtained.   The resulting continuum model was then applied to a more complex system, showing good agreement with particle-level simulations.  Accordingly, the order-of-magnitude discrepancy previously observed for empirical correlations was effectively eliminated.
